title: Ticket #7367: Jobs not getting OOM killed when out of memory
description:
When cgroups are enabled in the vanilla universe, the starter subscribed to per-cgroup OOM killer notification. When the OOM killer fires, it can be because 1 of 2 reasons:

1) Processes in this cgroup are using more memory than their limit. 2) Processes in this cgroup are below their memory limit, but processes outside cgroup limits (usually everything on the system that isn't a condor job.

A while back, we decided to not kill a job in case #2, and continue running, to allow the system to choose something else to kill. To make this decision, we compare the amount of memory used by the processes in the cgroup vs the limit.

However, there's a bug in our implementation. Our code to measure the amount of memory used simply totals rss + total_mapped_file. The OOM limit is based on all used pages, including various kernel structures. When we first implemented this, we hacked around this by coding a 10% buffer.

This buffer was removed in ticket #6925. Since this commit, CHTC gets jobs stuck, repeatedly hitting the OOM killer, but not putting them on hold.

In the short term, I'm going to restore the 10% buffer, and in the long term, give condor the ability to read the total amount of memory a cgroup is using, as viewed by the OOM limit.
